conclusion: Determine the moment when the light beam emerges from the arc surface ABC after entering the transparent brick.
Laser beam enters the transparent brick at point D on the left side, travels through the brick, and exits through the arc surface ABC.
The exit point depends on the angle of incidence and the refractive index of the material.
Need to find the point where the beam will emerge from the arc surface.
Beam will exit if the angle of incidence is such that the light does not undergo total internal reflection.
Snell's law: n sin(θ_i) = sin(θ_r). Critical angle for total internal reflection: sin(θ_c) = 1/n.
For light to exit the arc, the angle of incidence must be less than the critical angle.
Maximum angle of incidence before total internal reflection occurs is θ_c.
Laser beam moves from A to C at speed V. Distance AC is 2r.
Time taken for the beam to move from A to C is t = 2r/V.
Beam exits the arc surface when the angle of incidence is exactly the critical angle.
This happens when the beam has traveled a distance R sin(θ_c) from A to the point of emergence.
Time taken for the beam to travel this distance is t = R sin(θ_c)/V = R/nV.
Moment when the light emerges from the arc surface ABC is R/nV.
